subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: Sorry I was careless in picking my word.  I meant to say that it seems not to be a good XP way.  Didn t mean to impose my opinion onto others. The method name
messageBody:
Sorry I was careless in picking my word. I meant to say that it seems not to be
a good XP way. Didn't mean to impose my opinion onto others.

The method name should tell you what this method is. So IMHO,
testNeedImplement() seems to fit better.

Second, a REAL post-it or a note at the back of your task card seem to work a
lot more effectively.

Actually, I applaud for the other post about the Calendar assertion. That seems
to be something novel. :)

Robert Watkins wrote:

> Shane Duan wrote:
> > Plus, I am sure that all the XP developers would strongly
> > disagree with the comment here. The closest way I can think
> > of is to name the method as test_NeedImplement() but it sure
> > looks weird.
> >
> > Mind if I ask why exactly do you want a empty test method
> > there? What is the difference if you just add the method later?
>
> XP developers will say nothing of the sort. If the comment is the simplest
> thing that works, go for it. FWIW, I would use the method name to tell me
> what I'm meant to be testing.
>
> As to why: it's a placeholder so you don't forget it. Consider it similar to
> a PostIt note.
>
> Robert.
>
> --
> "Duct tape is like the Force: it has a light side, a dark side,
> and it holds the universe together"
> Robert Watkins robertdw@... robertw@...
